messages: 75dd2071a30b7c94d9361f05f06d524c (11:43): last time i looked, mysql implemented the wonderfully unscalable one-thread-per-connection model, so i doubt it cares much about ipc
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (11:44): it still does that, but innodb has its own thread stuff as well, i think
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (11:44): twincest, libkeiser: they're designed for different target markets
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (11:44): innodb is really a lot better than the rest of mysql ;-)
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (11:47): LeftWing: I used PostgreSQL to be the back-end for roller here @ home
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (11:48): got a handy digicam to take a screenshot with?
d91102e790545be0a09c1f715ac4926b (11:48): Postgres has had a few issues over time, but I think that 8.1 and up are pretty solid.  And it's much more SQL than MySQL is. =P
d91102e790545be0a09c1f715ac4926b (11:49): twincest: Yes, it's heading in the right direction I suppose, but it still feels like a toy. =P
75dd2071a30b7c94d9361f05f06d524c (11:49): does mysql even follow ACID semantics yet?
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (11:50): yes, if you use InnoDB
75dd2071a30b7c94d9361f05f06d524c (11:50): not long ago it deviated in some pretty egregious ways...
d91102e790545be0a09c1f715ac4926b (11:50): The pain with InnoDB is that you've got to pay for the hot-backup solution if memory serves.
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (11:51): you can run mysqldump in a transaction ;-)
d91102e790545be0a09c1f715ac4926b (11:51): twincest: That answer is one of my problems with MySQL. ;)
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (11:51): that's okay for us though, we need backups in a different form anyway, so we don't bother with database dumps
42296120bab4fc9174022209fe5c79f5 (11:52): jmcp: i've taken a screenshot but i can't figure out how to get linux to talk to my digital camera
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (11:54): doesn't it attach as an ordinary usb storage device?
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (11:54): there are two ways - storage or "usb p2p" - for the latter, you need gphoto or similar tools
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (11:55): can you change it to usb instead?
42296120bab4fc9174022209fe5c79f5 (11:55): no you don't seem to be able to
ec8870145320c70838038be9fc5b9cd4 (12:02): in case of a panic, I see that it saves a file under /var/crash/mchineName : is there a way to view the exact error ?
